title: Modeling a Non-Periodic Context - Exponential Function

content.description:
An ecologist began studying a certain type of plant species in a wetlands area in 2013. In 2015 (<math alttext="t equals 2"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>), there were <math alttext="59"><mn>59</mn></math> plants. In 2021 (<math alttext="t equals 8"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math>), there were <math alttext="118"><mn>118</mn></math> plants.  

The number of plants of this species can be modeled by the function <math alttext="P"><mi>P</mi></math> given by <math alttext="P open parentheses t close parentheses equals a b to the power of t"><mi>P</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>b</mi><mi>t</mi></msup></math>, where <math alttext="P open parentheses t close parentheses"><mi>P</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced></math> is the number of plants during year <math alttext="t"><mi>t</mi></math>, and <math alttext="t"><mi>t</mi></math> is the number of years since 2013
content.question:
Part A

(i) Use the given data to write two equations that can be used to find the values for constants <math> <mi>a</mi> </math> and <math> <mi>b</mi> </math> in the expression for <math alttext="P open parentheses t close parentheses"> <mi>P</mi> <mfenced> <mi>t</mi> </mfenced> </math>.

(ii) Find the values for <math> <mi>a</mi> </math> and <math> <mi>b</mi> </math> as decimal approximations.

frqParts.text:
Part A

(i) Use the given data to write two equations that can be used to find the values for constants <math> <mi>a</mi> </math> and <math> <mi>b</mi> </math> in the expression for <math alttext="P open parentheses t close parentheses"> <mi>P</mi> <mfenced> <mi>t</mi> </mfenced> </math>.

(ii) Find the values for <math> <mi>a</mi> </math> and <math> <mi>b</mi> </math> as decimal approximations.

Part B

(i) Use the given data to find the average rate of change of the number of plants, in plants per year, from <math alttext="t equals 2"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math> to <math alttext="t equals 8"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math> years. Express your answer as a decimal approximation. Show the computations that lead to your answer.

(ii) Use the average rate of change found in part B (i) to estimate the number of plants for <math alttext="t equals 10"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math> years. Show the work that leads to your answer.

(iii) The average rate of change found in part B (i) can be used to estimate the number of plants during year <math alttext="t"><mi>t</mi></math>, for <math alttext="t greater than 10"><mi>t</mi><mo>></mo><mn>10</mn></math> years. Are these estimates, found using the average rate of change, less than or greater than the number of plants predicted by the model <math alttext="P"><mi>P</mi></math> during year <math alttext="t"><mi>t</mi></math>, for <math alttext="t greater than 10"><mi>t</mi><mo>></mo><mn>10</mn></math> years? Explain your reasoning. Your explanation should include a reference to the graph of <math alttext="P"><mi>P</mi></math> and its relationship to the estimates found using the average rate of change.

Part C

In which <math alttext="t"><mi>t</mi></math>-value, <math alttext="t equals 6"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math> years or <math alttext="t equals 20"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></math> years, should the ecologist have more confidence when using the model <math alttext="P"><mi>P</mi></math> ? Give a reason for your answer in the context of the problem.
